Grismer, L. L. 2002. Amphibians and reptiles of Baja California including its Pacific islands and islands in the Sea of Cortes. University of California Press, Berkeley, California.
Degenhardt, W.G., C.W. Painter and A.H. Price. 1996. Amphibians and Reptiles of New Mexico. University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque, New Mexico.

Matthews, K. R., R. A. Knapp, and K. L. Pope. 2002. Garter snake distributions in high-elevation aquatic ecosystems: is there a link with declining amphibian populations and nonnative trout introductions? Journal of Herpetology 36:16-22.
Hammerson, G. 1999.  Amphibians and reptiles in Colorado. Second edition. University Press of Colorado and Colorado Division of Wildlife.Niwot, Colorado, USA.
Collins, J. T. 1990. Standard common and current scientific names for North American amphibians and reptiles. SSAR Herpetol. Circular No. 19. 41 pp.
Russell, A. P., and A. M. Bauer. 1993. The amphibians and reptiles of Alberta. University of Calgary Press, Calgary, Alberta, and University of Alberta Press, Edmonton, Alberta. 264 pp.
Tanner, W. W., and C. H. Lowe. 1989. Variations in THAMNOPHIS ELEGANS with descriptions of new subspecies. Great Basin Nat. 49:511-516.
Fitch, H. S. 1983. Thamnophis elegans. Cat. Am. Amph. Rep. 320.1-320.4.
Jennings, W. B., D. F. Bradford, and D. F. Johnson. 1992. Dependence of the garter snake THAMNOPHIS ELEGANS on amphibians in the Sierra Nevada of California. J. Herpetol. 26:503-505.

The Reptiles of British Columbia: Western Terrestrial (Wandering) Garter Snake, Thamnophis elegans vagrans. 2004. Univ. College of the Cariboo, and B.C. Minist. Water, Land and Air Prot. Online. Available: http://www.bcreptiles.ca/snakes/westterrgarter.html
Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
Nussbaum, R.A., E.D. Brodie, Jr., and R.M. Storm. 1983. Amphibians and Reptiles of the Pacific Northwest. University Press of Idaho, Moscow, Idaho. 332 pp.
Bronikowski, A. M., and S. J. Arnold. 2001. Cytochrome b phylogeny does not match subspecific classification in the western terrestrial garter snake, THAMNOPHIS ELEGANS. Copeia 2001:508-513.
Cook, F. R. 1984. Introduction to Canadian amphibians and reptiles. National Museum of Natural Sciences, National Museums of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario.
Rossman, D. A., N. B. Ford, and R. A. Seigel. 1996. The garter snakes: evolution and ecology. University of Oklahoma Press, Norman. 332 pp
NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
Stebbins, R.C. 2003. A field guide to western reptiles and amphibians.  Third Edition. Houghton Mifflin, Boston.
habitat_description:
The terrestrial gartersnake is found from central British Columbia, southwestern Manitoba, and central Alberta into most of the western United States; western South Dakota, western Nebraska, extreme western Oklahoma, Colorado, and New Mexico. Isolated populations from the main range are found in northern Baja California (Grismer 2002; Rossman et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003). 
 
This species burrows in or using soil, decaying logs, and fallen debris. Its habitat includes herbaceous wetland, low to moderate gradient creeks and rivers, shallow water pools. Also riparian zones, grassland, chaparral, bare rock, talus, scree, shrubland, and conifer, hardwood, mixed woodland. Populations are found in lowlands to high mountains, and open forest areas (Natureserve.org).

NW	-Cover is provided by densely vegetated patches of shrubs and grasses found along creeks, rivers, ponds, and lakes.
